Award.AwardTitle: Dense Solid Mixtures to Multifunctional Hybrid Carbon/Low Z Networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Abstract:
Most materials in the universe experience extreme conditions of high pressure and high temperature, which exist deep in the planets and stars. Under such conditions, first- and second-row (or low Z) elemental solids, while existing as simple molecular or elemental solids at ambient conditions, form unusual and highly dense network structures. These materials are extremely hard, have high energy density, and exhibit novel optical and electronic properties. These novel properties arise from collective behaviors of 3D network structures of low Z elements with high phonon frequencies, thermal conductivities, cohesive energies, and strong electron-phonon couplings. The structures and properties of these densely packed low Z solids, therefore, can be viewed as nature's windows to unexplored novel structures and properties beyond those of diamond and transition metal compounds. However, these materials are often formed at formidable pressures and may be unstable at normal conditions; only a few systems have been recovered, limiting the materials within a realm of fundamental scientific discoveries. Therefore, an exciting new research area has emerged on understanding and, ultimately, controlling the stability, bonding, structure, and properties of low Z extended solids.

Technical Abstract:
This project aims to develop multifunctional hybrid carbon/low-Z extended solids amenable to stabilization at ambient conditions via kinetically controlled processes in heterogeneous solid mixtures. State of the art dynamic-diamond anvil cell experiments coupled with time-resolved Raman and synchrotron X-ray characterization are used to probe metastable interfacial structures and exploit the presence of internal chemical pressure and dynamic shears, thereby lowering the external transition pressure while enhancing the miscibility between two dislike solids. Through scientific discoveries and innovative material developments, the project elucidates the fundamental principles of high-pressure chemistry and demonstrate the revolutionary capabilities of hybrid carbon/low Z framework materials for hydrogen storage, chemical energy depository, and nonlinear optical and electronic applications. The project also provides graduate and undergraduate students with significant hands-on opportunities to learn experimental technologies at our institution, at the synchrotron and neutron facilities, and in national laboratories. Because of the multidisciplinary nature of this effort, these students are gaining fundamental knowledge across many academic disciplines of solid-state chemistry, condensed matter physics, and materials and planetary sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to develop multifunctional hybrid carbon/low-Z extended solids amenable to stabilization at ambient conditions via kinetic controlled processes in heterogeneous dense solid mixtures. We investigate the phase stability, metastable structure, structural miscibility, and collective properties of lattice phonons and electrons in dense solid mixtures at high pressures and elucidate insights into the structure-bond-properties relationships of dense carbons/low Z and metals/low Z hybrid materials. This in turn guides us to synthesize new materials and novel structures in more controlled and directed ways. Consequently, the proposed research will contribute to establishing the basic principles of solid-state combinatory chemistry in dense solid mixtures and, thereby, accelerating the development of new materials.

 

The research effort in this year has been focused on the investigation of novel states and chemistry of dense elementary solids abundant in deep planetary interiors at extreme pressures and temperatures. Several major progresses have been made amid the subject areas of:

1. Chemistry of Dense Solids under Extreme Conditions, 

2. Synthesis of New Materials and Novel Extended Structures of Low Z Molecular Solids at High Pressures

3. Fundamental Properties of Quantum Solids Mixtures at High Pressures. 

4. Electronic Metal-Insulator Transitions in Transition Metal Complexes under Pressure.

5. Thermomechanical and Photochemical Reactions under Extreme Conditions:

6.  Collaboration and Technology Developments

The scientific and materials knowledge obtained through this research have enabled us to direct and control strong chemical bonds and solid-state reactions at the molecular, atomic and electronic levels by application of large compression at bond energies and to tune structures and novel properties of the products in predictive ways. This project to date has resulted in several major discoveries of new states of matter and chemistry occurring in dense molecular solids, quantum solids, and functional transition metal oxides under extreme conditions. 

These research efforts have resulted in twenty-one peer-reviewed papers and two conference proceedings; provided research opportunities to six PhD students, two MS students, one undergraduate student, two Post-Doctoral researchers, and one Senior Research Scientist in the PI’s High Pressure Group at WSU; and produced one new PhD: Sakun Duwal (PhD in Chemistry, WSU, May 2018) and two MS Students: Kevin Hernandez (MS in Chemistry, WSU, May 2020); Karrisa Jenson (MS in Chemistry, WSU, May 2020).

Modified by: Choong-Shik Yoo
